metadata.case_name: Raja Anand Brahma Shah v. State of Uttar Pradesh

facts.text: Appellant was the Zamindar of Pargana Agori lying to the south of Kaimur Range in the district of Mirzapur.

On October 4, 1950, a notification was issued by the State Government under s. 4 of the Land Acquisition Act stating that the area of 409.6 acres in the village of Markundi Ghurma Pargana Agori was needed for a public purpose, specified as limestone quarry; urgency under s. 17(1) and direction under s. 17(4) that s. 5A provisions would not apply.

On October 12, 1950, a further notification under s. 6 declaring Governor satisfied land needed for public purpose, directing Collector to take order for acquisition under s. 7, and under s. 17(1) to take possession of waste or arable land after notice u/s 9(1).
On November 19, 1950, possession of the land was taken by the Collector of Mirzapur and handed over to the Administrative Officer, Government Cement Factory, Churk.
An award was made by the Land Acquisition Officer on January 7, 1952 stating compensation Rs. 23,638/13/7.
Appellant filed application under s. 18 for reference to Civil Court; reference made as Land Acquisition Reference No. 4 of 1952, still pending.

On May 2, 1955, appellant filed Writ Petition No. 454 of 1955 in Allahabad High Court alleging acquisition not for public purpose, no jurisdiction for s.17 as land not waste or arable, owns mines and minerals entitled to compensation therefor; prayed for certiorari to quash s.4 and s.6 notifications and proceedings, and mandamus for compensation for limestone removed.

Allahabad High Court by judgment dated November 2, 1962 dismissed writ petition holding: (1) petitioner not owner of mines/minerals, not entitled to compensation; (2) land acquired for public purpose; (3) s.17 applicable, no illegality in notifications.
Collector's Inspection Note dated December 15, 1951 noted one lac of trees in acquired land: Tendu, Asan, Sidh, Bijaisal, Khair, bamboo clumps, Mahuwa, Kakora.

Historical: Ancestors owned Parganas Agori and Barhar since 13th century; Sanads: Oct 9, 1781 by Warren Hastings restoring with all ancient rights; Oct 15, 1781 Jagir; Dec 10, 1803 confirming permanently as immovable Jagirdar of Mahal and everything appertaining thereto.
Intermediary interest of appellant in Pargana Agori vested in State of U.P. by notifications June 30, 1953 and July 1, 1953 under U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1951 as amended.
Wajibularz and subordinate leases show appellant enjoyed mineral rights, leased coal to Mr. Burke, etc.

legal_issues.text: Whether the notification under s. 4 dated October 4, 1950 is liable to be quashed on the ground that the acquisition was not for a public purpose.
Whether the land is waste or arable land enabling application of s. 17(1) and (4), dispensing with s. 5A inquiry.
Whether the appellant had sub-soil and mineral rights in the areas and entitled to compensation for minerals including limestone.

petitioner_arguments.text: Acquisition not for public purpose as limestone used for cement sold for profit in open market, not for public work of construction.
Land neither waste nor arable (forest land with large number of trees as per Collector's note), so no jurisdiction under s.17(1)/(4); High Court can review preliminary fact finding.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Land Acquisition Act s.17(1),(4); R.V. Shoreditch Assessment Committee

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellant owns mines and minerals per Sanads of 1781 and 1803 granting land and everything appertaining thereto; entitled to compensation.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sanads 1781, 1803; Regulation VIII of 1793; precedents like Hari Narayan Singh v. Sriram Chakravarti

respondent_arguments.text: Limestone utilised in public sector cement factory at Churk; production important for national interest e.g. Rihand dam; even if sold for profit, benefits state revenues.
s.17(4) depends on subjective opinion of State Government that s.17(1) applicable; conclusive unless mala fide.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Land Acquisition Act s.17(4); King Emperor v. Shibnath Banerjee

court_reasoning.text: Declaration u/s 6(3) conclusive that land needed for public purpose unless colourable exercise of power; appellant failed to show colourable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Principle from Smt. Somavanti v. State of Punjab applies; no evidence of colourable exercise.

court_reasoning.text: Land not waste or arable: covered by trees (Collector's note), not fit for ploughing/tillage or barren/desolate; s.17(1) condition precedent for jurisdiction, reviewable by court.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Oxford Dictionary definitions; wrongly deciding character of land does not confer jurisdiction.

court_reasoning.text: s.17(4) subjective but challengeable if no application of mind or mala fide; here land not waste/arable, so invalid direction dispensing s.5A.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Inference State did not honestly form opinion; precedents like Estate and Trust Agencies Ltd. v. Singapore.

court_reasoning.text: Sanads grant land and 'everything appertaining thereto'; no reservation of minerals; prima facie surface owner entitled to sub-soil; supported by history, regulations, conduct.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Permanent settlement recognized zamindars as proprietors of soil including minerals.

holdings.text: s.6 declaration conclusive unless colourable; not shown here.
Land not waste or arable; State had no jurisdiction under s.17(1)/(4); notifications u/s 4 and 6 ultra vires; proceedings quashed.
Appellant owner of sub-soil minerals; High Court view overruled.

precedents_cited.case_name: Smt. Somavanti v. The State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Declaration u/s 6 conclusive subject to colourable exercise exception.
Court can review preliminary fact for jurisdiction in certiorari.

precedents_cited.case_name: White and Collins v. Minister of Health
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court entitled to determine if preliminary finding of fact correct.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jaichand Lal Sethia v. State of West Bengal
Estate and Trust Agencies Ltd. v. Singapore Improvement Trust
precedents_cited.relevance: Challenge to subjective declaration if beyond terms or wrong ground.
Infer no honest opinion if no grounds.
Review if no evidence for jurisdictional fact.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hari Narayan Singh v. Sriram Chakravarti
precedents_cited.relevance: Zamindar owner of underground rights unless parted with.

precedents_cited.case_name: Durga Prasad Singh v. Braja Nath Bose
precedents_cited.relevance: Minerals not part of tenure grant absent express terms.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sashi Bhushan Misra v. Jyoti Prasad Singh Deo
precedents_cited.relevance: Minerals not included in zamindar tenure grants.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ranjit Singh v. Kali Dasi Debi
precedents_cited.relevance: Settlement recognizes zamindars as proprietors of soil.

statutes_cited.name: Land Acquisition Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs acquisition procedure; s.17 urgency for waste/arable land dispensing s.5A; notifications invalid as land not qualifying.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Intermediary interest vested in State; bars restoration of possession.

statutes_cited.name: Mirzapur Stone Mahal Act (U.P. Act V of 1886)
statutes_cited.relevance: Regulates quarrying but does not affect proprietor's sub-soil mineral rights.

statutes_cited.name: Regulation VIII of 1793
statutes_cited.relevance: Settlement with actual proprietors of soil.

statutes_cited.name: Regulation II of 1793
statutes_cited.relevance: Property in soil vested in landholders.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed to extent indicated: writ of certiorari granted quashing s.4 notification dated Oct 4, 1950 applying s.17(1)/(4) and dispensing s.5A; s.6 notification Oct 12, 1950 and all subsequent proceedings including award and reference quashed; claim for restoration of possession rejected as vested under Zamindari Abolition Act; High Court judgment set aside; no order as to costs.
outcome.relief_granted: Quashing of notifications and proceedings; declaration of mineral ownership (implicit).

key_quotes.text: the declaration made by the State Government in the notification under s. 6(1) of the Act, that the land was required for a public purpose, is made conclusive by sub-s. (3) of s. 6
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Holds public purpose declaration conclusive unless colourable.

key_quotes.text: the land sought to be acquired is not waste land or arable land within the meaning of s. 17(1) or (4) of the Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: You ought to consider him the Raja of immovable Jagir and of Mahal and everything appertaining thereto belongs to him.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From 1803 Sanad; crux for mineral rights vesting in appellant.

key_quotes.text: the zamindars have had at least a prima facie title to all lands for which they pay revenue
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Ranjit Singh; supports zamindar proprietary rights including sub-soil.
